You've decided to live in the woods and now have to make up the surroundings/story by drawing cards from a deck. And it was so fun and wholesome and idyllic..    And when we were done all three of us just kinda sat there on the floor, looking at the map we had created of our little cabin, our animals and all the mysterious, creepy and magical things surrounding us. Runes, ancient technology, a creepy, lone standing door, this fea dude in a bordeaux suit and top hat. And we all kinda wished that we could actually live there.  TLDR: me and two D&D friends played a one shot about escaping into a magical forest, and all mourn that we couldn't live there irl.

We're having a huge problem with people stealing Catalytic converters in Portland Oregon too. My work has two box trucks they use to help people move or clear abandoned apartments. First, we had to get a locking gas cap because they kept stealing the gas, then when they couldn't do that anymore, they stole the catalytic converters. Some co-workers/tenants got theirs stolen off their personal vehicles as well. I think the only reason why my mom hasn't gotten hers stolen is because it's pretty buried in the rest of the mechanicals. Kia sportage for the win!

BROO, I live in Richmond and my Prius catalytic converter just got stolen too. Because of the supply shortage they can sell them for even more for scrap. It's getting so wild that some states (Washington for example) are trying to introduce new laws about selling scraps. My partner posted on our neighborhood website that mine got stolen and found a thread with over 100 people in the last month whose got stolen in Richmond. Pruis is especially vulnerable to it. WILDDDD Be careful out there folks. I ended up selling my car anyways, but you bet I'll have cameras on my next car. LOL

1:25 lmao Garrett ily man but agnostic just refers to believing the fact the existence or lack thereof a higher power is unprovable and unknowable (at least currently), that enough evidence has not been provided to objectively determine any such existence, and PROBABLY MAYBE never will. It's basically shrugging as a religious designation. Believing in/worshipping everything/every god is Omnitheism, or Pantheism (though I more often see Pantheism used to refer to deification of the universe so I usually use omnitheism). So it sounds like you'd technically be an agnostic omnitheist/omnitheist agnostic, since you seem like a bit of both.
As a fellow agnostic, "I'll just die and see what happens" is the perfect way to describe my feelings on the matter. I will now be stealing this saying, and hopefully that doesn't come back to bit me in whatever form the afterlife might take. ğŸ˜˜

Some things you may not think to do/bring but I think are good ideas:   â€¢find out what time sunset is so you can plan your day accordingly  â€¢ something that's not a phone, only meant for music, to distract from scary noises (with headphones, they save battery life)   â€¢ compass   â€¢ thermal clothes AND sleeping bag   â€¢ as much water as as you can carry, bubbly celtzer is not a bad idea because its lighter, use 0 calorie ones, nothing sugary that'll make you more thirsty or potentially dehydrated.   â€¢ no shame in going back car to sleep (get there before sunset)  â€¢ take a walk with everything you're carrying to see how much you can endure. Try to avoid making 2 trips.  â€¢ try to be as close to car as possible   â€¢ not the worst idea to leave car unlocked if you need to run and get In fast. Relatively unlikely someone would steal it if you're far away from people.   I once tried to drive 4 hours to another state to run away too and only got 45 minutes into it before I got pulled over, the cop treated me the way I wished cops treated everyone. #whitegirlprivilege he showed me where parking lots were, so I chilled there because I was getting tired. I stayed in the lot for maybe 30 minuets before deciding to go back home because there were no hotels open. I didn't really feel failure, I felt more like I made a smarter decision. And you did too.

Just to clarify - agnostic doesn't mean you believe in _everything_ ; it means you admit the afterlife/higher-power is unknowable and/or incomprehensible to our level of thought, so you're sufficed to live a relatively "good" life and think the higher-power, if there is one, will accept that you couldn't have known of them and will accept your relative goodness.  I personally think the idea of praise/worship is very vain/conceited for a deity, which is one of my main qualms with _organized_ religion.

This is funny and all but i don't think y'all want to do this irl. Aside from probably being illegal and trespassing, going off a trail is extremely dangerous. What could feel like just a few feet could be enough to completely turn you around in the wilderness. People die doing this. I know we like this man-childlike behavior as entertainment but please do NOT do this. If you want an escape, actually take the time to find a campground. Your fees will go to a state park and help preserve it and it will be just as rewarding. Bring more than enough food and water and an adult coloring book or something.

There's private property woods, there's public forests which would be the common collective forests for the people of the nation, that's a state park or national park, and there are novelty campgrounds, church owned camp grounds, college university owned woods, or rent a place that has woods, vacation property with woods. there are insurance liabilities and water rights involved with land, it can't just be whimsical freedom fairyland.  sorry bud.

For anyone who may have missed Garrettâ€™s disclaimer - DO NOT ACTUALLY DO THIS. What he did (at least as he presented it) is incredibly dangerous. If you are going to go out into the wilderness, you need to make sure people know where you are going and when you plan to come back. You need to have water (or a way to filter water), food (or know how to forage), shelter, a way to maintain your body temperature, sufficient first aid, and a way to navigate. Ideally, you will also have a way to communicate if youâ€™re going into the back country. Additionally, you should always abide by the Leave No Trace principles (so definitely donâ€™t leave a trail of cookies for a bear to both become accustomed to people food as well as to have an easy way to find you while you sleep).    I know this was more for entertainment than anything, but the amount of times people get lost and need SAR or die from doing this same kind of thing without proper supplies, planning, and experience is far too high. Absolutely, get out into nature and experience that freedom and peace, but do it safely and in a way that wonâ€™t leave a negative impact on nature.

Are you agnostic, or a gnostic? Because I think we're operating on opposing definitions. Gnostic means 'to know', so agnostic means not knowing. An agnostic just has the mindset that we can't possibly know some things, but is not opposed to accepting something should truth arise.   Unless you mean you are an agnostic theist, rather than the type of atheist it tends to describe. I'll admit, I haven't run across many agnostic theists. I wonder if that would be someone who does not know if something doesn't exist...? Like, ghosts have no been definitively proven or disproven, so you'll believe until proven otherwise...? are lobsters immortal?  Contrary to popular belief, lobsters are not immortal. ... Eventually, the lobster will die from exhaustion during a moult. Older lobsters are also known to stop moulting, which means that the shell will eventually become damaged, infected, or fall apart and they die.

If your freezer works, your fridge works. Cool air is blown from the freezer into the fridge. What has likely happened is that condensation has frozen around the fan and is preventing it from blowing the cool air into the fridge. Unplug the fridge and let is sit for awhile so it defrosts, and then plug it back in and you should be good.

I rarely leave comments but this video had me feel so many wonderful things especially being someone who would spend every summer in the beautiful mountains so I some knowledge that I would like to share in case you go back to the mountains again (with Andrew hopefully! I would love to see you both out in the wilderness having fun). First, unrelated to camping but in this video you look like Rhettâ€™s long lost twin and I died of laughter at your search history! First bit of nature info, the vast majority of bats are not harmful! The only bat the sucks blood is the â€œvampire batâ€ which usually suck on cow blood, but if they do bite humans (which is fairly rare) they do it when the human is asleep. While you sleep, they bite the tip of your nose and take only a little bit of blood (vampire bats are actually very small so they donâ€™t take that much blood) Usually, the bite is supposedly painless as most people donâ€™t know that they were bit until they wake up and see two tiny dots on the tip of their nose. However, maybe get a rabies shot if that happens, but most people act like if they are bit by a vampire bat that itâ€™s going to suck out all of their blood and like I said they only take a little bit of blood. Also, I believe most bats enjoy snacking in insects and fruits the most. Bats are such cool creatures which people freak out but most bats are usually harmless. Unrelated to nature, I can only imagine what it would have been like to be pulled over by police with several skeletons, a demented doll, a bear costume, a shovel, and a keyboard! Lol! Going back to nature, bears are so cool! They are majestic creatures and I love them, but they can be dangerous when people who donâ€™t know the protocol for dealing with bears. Hopefully, this will help you if you go back out into nature. If you see a bear, and it is approaching you or too close for your comfort, you are supposed to make yourself as big as possible (fully extend your arms out, go up on your tip toes etc) and make LOTS of noise. Definitely do not try to run or attack the bear because that is a fight you most likely will not win. Bears are incredibly smart, gorgeous, and strong! Our camp had â€œbear proofâ€ dumpsters which was supposed to be made to prevent bears from getting in there and digging through the trash for scraps and making a messâ€¦the bears figured out how to open the dumpster which was like solid metal with some sort of crazy locking mechanics so I would not aggravate them and definitely keep your distance! Most likely they will leave you alone if you leave them alone. It is really cool and quite majestic to be in the close (but safe distance) vicinity of a bear. I have been lucky enough to see bears in the wild â€œcloseâ€ up. There you just stay quiet and watch, donâ€™t make sudden movement or loud noises as that will frighten it and put you on its radar as a threat which you donâ€™t want. If that happens then using the getting big technique as I mentioned earlier is definitely a lifesaving thing to know. Stamp your feet, yell, scream, bang pots together if you have those while making yourself as big as possible. Also, when in the woods do NOT leave any food in the car! Bears have an incredible sense of smell and they will break into your car and steal your food! We one time had bear paw prints around the car and ON the car window! Thankfully, we did not have any food in there because that bear would have smashed in the window (they have big strong paws). When in the woods you should hang your food in a bag and put it high up in a tree with a rope (preferably a tree that is a little ways from your setup spot so you donâ€™t lead the bear directly to your tent) (Also, I should state that hanging your food may not be the best way to go anymore as Iâ€™m sure they probably sell certain camping supplies now designed for that, but Iâ€™m not sure. I always thought it was strange to hang up your food when we know that bears can climb treesâ€¦so maybe pick a skinny tree that wonâ€™t hold the weight of a bear but isnâ€™t so fragile that the bear can push it over). Bears are such amazing creatures and when people donâ€™t know the proper protocol to use thatâ€™s when bear attacks happen and then they have to put the bear down. Bears have such a sad history with humans hunting them to the point of near extinction so knowing the protocol you protect yourself and you protect the bear. Also, if you see a mama bear with a cubâ€¦Stay as far away as possible because mama bears will do anything and everything to protect their Cubs! The cubs are cute but admire them from a long distance. Also, Iâ€™m so glad that you mentioned that while it was fun to go into the woods definitely donâ€™t go alone. It kind of depends on the type of comfort I'm looking for, if I need something to just sit in front of and pretend I'm not an adult, I'll go for something I watched a lot as a kid like Labyrinth or Matilda. If I'm specifically bogged down with the weight of modern problems, I'll watch something like 10 things i hate about you or mean girls, any teen-ish movie from around that era. But there's a specific kind of comfort I need sometimes that I don't know how to explain... and it comes from watching Bridge to Terabithia, specifically because (SPOILER ALERT I guess) the character with my name dies. I don't know why I need this sometimes but it gives me a really specific catharsis that I don't get from anything else.
